greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array T(j,k) read by antidiagonals upwards, in which column k lists the numbers n having k odd divisors greater than sqrt(2*n), with j >= 1, k >= 0.
comment: Conjecture: column k lists also the numbers n having k pairs of equidistant subparts in the symmetric representation of sigma(n).
For more information about the "subparts" see A279387.
This sequence is a permutation of the natural numbers.
link: Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
example: The upper-left corner of the square array begins:
mathematica: jMax = 11; nMax = 5000; cnt[n_] := cnt[n] = DivisorSum[n, Boole[OddQ[#] && # > Sqrt[2n]]&]; col[k_] := Select[Range[nMax], cnt[#] == k&]; T[j_, k_] := col[k][[j]]; Table[T[j-k, k], {j, 1, jMax}, {k, 0, j-1}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 16 2017 *)
xref: Column 0 gives A082662. The rest of the terms are in A281005 in increasing order.
results.author: _Omar E. Pol_, Feb 15 2017
